columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value of the project using the given details.

The net present value is a measure of a firm or a project's profitability. It takes the cash inflow and outflow of the cash. A positive net present value means that the project is profitable. 

It can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\text{Cash inflow for Year 1}}{(1+\text{required return})^1}+\dfrac{\text{Cash inflow for Year 2}}{(1+\text{required return})^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{Cash inflow for Year 3}}{(1+\text{required return})^3}+\dfrac{\text{Cash inflow for Year 4}}{(1+\text{required return})^4}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{Cash inflow for Year 5}}{(1+\text{required return})^5}-\text{Initial investment}
\end{aligned}$$

In order to solve for the cash inflow, we will first solve for the annual sales. To do this, we will multiply the price by the number of units sold.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=\$535 \times155,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$82,925,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 1 is $\$82,925,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=\$535 \times165,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$88,275,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 2 is $\$88,275,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=\$535 \times125,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$66,875,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 3 is $\$66,875,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=\$535 \times 95,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$50,825,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 4 is $\$50,825,000$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=\$535 \times 75,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$40,125,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 5 is $\$40,125,000$

In the problem, it was stated that the sales will drop by $30,000$ units. We can then solve for the Sales lost by multiplying this number by the price of the old units.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sales lost}&=30,000 \times \$385\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,550,000
\end{aligned}$$

The revenue lost if the new smartphone models are not released is $\$11,550,000$

Next, we can solve for the lost revenue of the first two years using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Revenue lost}&=(\text{Number of old units sold}-\text{Decrease in number of units})\\
&\times(\text{Price of smartphone if new model is not released}-\text{Price of smartphone if new model is released})
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the revenue lost in **Year 1**, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Revenue lost}&=(155,000-30,000)\\
&\times(\$385-\$215)\\[15 pt]
&=\$21,250,000
\end{aligned}$$

The revenue lost in Year 1 is $\$21,250,000$

For the revenue lost in **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Revenue lost}&=(165,000-30,000)\\
&\times(\$385-\$215)\\[15 pt]
&=\$22,950,000
\end{aligned}$$

The revenue lost in Year 2 is $\$22,950,000$

Since we already have the sales lost and revenue lost, we can solve for the net sales for Years 1 and 2. To do this, simply take the annual sales then subtract the sales lost and revenue lost.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net sales}&=\$82,925,000-\$11,550,000-\$21,250,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$50,125,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net sales for Year 1 is $\$50,125,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net sales}&=\$88,275,000-\$11,550,000-\$22,950,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$53,775,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net sales for Year 2 is $\$53,775,000$

For the variable cost, we will simply take the number of units sold per year then, multiply the cost.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=155,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$34,100,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 1 is $\$34,100,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=165,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$36,300,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 2 is $\$36,300,000$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=125,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,500,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 3 is $\$27,500,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=95,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$20,900,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 4 is $\$20,900,000$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=75,000 \times \$220\\[15 pt]
&=\$16,500,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for Year 5 is $\$16,500,000$

Next, we will then take the variable cost for the sales lost. To do this, we will multiply the decrease in the number of units sold by the variable cost if the new units are not released.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost of sales lost}&=30,000 \times \$145\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,350,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost of sales lost is $\$4,350,000$

The net variable cost for Years 1 and 2 can be solved by subtracting the annual variable cost by the variable cost of the sales lost.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net variable cost}&=\$34,100,000 -\$4,350,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$29,750,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net variable cost for Year 1 is $\$29,750,000$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net variable cost}&=\$36,300,000 -\$4,350,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$31,950,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net variable cost for Year 2 is $\$31,950,000$

For the amount of depreciation, we will use the Modified Accelerated Cash Recovery System which uses a set of rates that will be multiplied to the initial investment per year. These are the rates that will be used for a 7-year MACRS where only the first 5 years will be used.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.1429\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.2449\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1749\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1249\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.0893
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the depreciation, we will get the following values:

For **Year 1**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1429\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,216,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 1 is $\$6,216,150$

For **Year 2**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.2449\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,653,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 2 is $\$10,653,150$

For **Year 3**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1749\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,608,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 3 is $\$7,608,150$

For **Year 4**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.1249\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,433,150
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 4 is $\$5,433,150$

For **Year 5**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$43,500,000 \times 0.0893\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,884,550
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 5 is $\$3,884,550$

Now that we have the depreciation, we can solve for the earnings before interest and tax. To do this, we will subtract the net variable cost, fixed cost, and depreciation from the annual sales.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$50,125,000-\$29,750,000\\
&-\$6,400,000-\$6,216,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,758,850
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 1 is $\$7,758,850$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$53,775,000-\$31,950,000\\
&-\$6,400,000-\$10,653,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,771,850
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 2 is $\$4,771,850$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$66,875,000-\$27,500,000\\
&-\$6,400,000-\$7,608,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$25,366,850
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 3 is $\$25,366,850$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$50,825,000-\$27,500,000\\
&-\$6,400,000-\$5,433,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,491,850
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 4 is $\$11,491,850$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings before interest and tax}&=\$40,125,000-\$16,500,000\\
&-\$6,400,000-\$3,884,550\\[15 pt]
&=\$13,340,450
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 5 is $\$13,340,450$

Now that we have the earnings before interest and tax, we will solve for the net income by multiplying the EBIT by one minus the tax rate.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$7,758,850 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,129,491.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income or Year 1 is $\$6,129,491.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$4,771,850 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,769,761.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income or Year 2 is $\$3,769,761.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$25,366,850 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$20,039,811.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income or Year 3 is $\$20,039,811.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$11,491,850 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$9,078,561.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income or Year 4 is $\$9,078,561.50$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$13,340,450 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,538,955.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income or Year 5 is $\$10,538,955.50$

To get the operating cash flow, take the net income then add back the depreciation.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$6,129,491.50+\$6,216,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$12,345,641.50
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 1 is $\$12,345,641.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$3,769,761.50+\$10,653,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$14,422,911.50
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 2 is $\$14,422,911.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$20,039,811.50+\$7,608,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,647,961.50
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 3 is $\$27,647,961.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$9,078,561.50+\$5,433,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$14,511,711.50
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 4 is $\$14,511,711.50$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$10,538,955.50+\$3,884,550\\[15 pt]
&=\$14,423,505.50
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for Year 5 is $\$14,423,505.50$

Next, we will solve for the net working capital. For **Year 1**, we will simply multiply the net sales by $20\%$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=\$50,125,000 \times 0.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,025,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 1 is $\$10,025,000$

For Years 2 to 4, to get the net working capital, we will take the $20\%$ of the net sales. After that, we will subtract the value by the net working capital of the previous Year.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=(\$53,775,000 \times 0.20) - \$10,025,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$730,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for **Year 2** is $\$730,000$

For **Year 3**, our net working capital will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=(\$66,875,000 \times 0.20)-\$730,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$12,645,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 3 is $\$12,645,000$

For **Year 4**, our net working capital will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=(\$50,825,000 \times 0.20)-\$12,645,000\\[15 pt]
&=-\$2,485,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 4 is $-\$2,485,000$

For **Year 5**, our net working capital will simply be the $20\%$ of the  sales of Year 4.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=\$50,825,000 \times 0.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,165,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 5 is $\$10,165,000$

Now that we have the net working capital, we can now solve for the cash inflow for each year. To do this, we will simply take the operating cash flow, then subtract the net working capital.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash inflow}&=\$12,345,641.50 -\$10,025,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,320,641.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cash inflow for Year 1 is $\$2,320,641.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash inflow}&=\$14,422,911.50 -\$730,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$13,692,911.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cash inflow for Year 2 is $\$13,692,911.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash inflow}&=\$27,647,961.50 -\$12,645,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$15,002,961.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cash inflow for Year 3 is $\$15,002,961.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash inflow}&=\$14,511,711.50 +\$2,485,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$16,996,711.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cash inflow for Year 4 is $\$16,996,711.50$

Before we get the cash inflow for Year 5, we will first solve for book value of the equipment. To do this, we will subtract the initial investment by the total depreciation.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value of equipment}&=\$43,500,000-\$33,795,150\\[15 pt]
&=\$9,704,850
\end{aligned}$$

The book value of the equipment is $\$9,704,850$

Next, we will get the cash flow of the sale of the equipment. This can be done by first taking the book value, subtracting the sale price of the equipment, then multiplying it to the tax rate to get the tax for the equipment.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax for the equipment}&=(\$9,704,850-\$6,500,000) \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$673,018.50
\end{aligned}$$

The tax for the equipment is $\$673,018.50$

Then, we will take this tax and add it to the sale price of the equipment to get the cash flow of the sale of the equipment.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow on sale of equipment}&=\$6,500,000 + \$673,018.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,173,018.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cash flow on the sale of the equipment is $\$7,173,018.50$

Now that we have this value, we can solve for the cash inflow for **Year 5** by taking the operating cash flow, adding the cash flow on the sale of the equipment, then subtracting the net working capital.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash inflow}&=\$14,423,505.50+\$7,173,018.50\\
&-\$10,165,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$11,431,524
\end{aligned}$$

The cash inflow for Year 5 is $\$11,431,524$

Now that we have the cash inflows, we can now solve for the net present value using the formula in Step 2.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=\dfrac{\$2,320,641.50}{(1+0.12)^1}+\dfrac{\$13,692,911.50}{(1+0.12)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$15,002,961.50}{(1+0.12)^3}+\dfrac{\$16,996,711.50}{(1+0.12)^4}\\
&+\dfrac{\$11,431,524}{(1+0.12)^5}-\$43,500,000\\[15 pt]
&=-\$2,545,010.64
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this project is $-\$2,545,010.64$
